overview: This subject provides an introduction to process work in process engineering, focusing specifically on process safety and sustainability. Material taught in other chemical engineering subjects will be reinforced via a series of assignments in which ill-defined and open-ended process engineering problems will be tackled. Both hypothetical and real case studies from the process engineering field are used throughout the subject.

Several assessment tasks combine to form a capstone project. Within this project students, in teams of three or four, perform design tasks related to the development of a Chemical Process Engineering facility. This capstone project culminates in an Environmental Effects Statement assignment. Several industry speakers, from the process engineering and environmental areas, talk and provide content to aid with this assignment.
intended learning outcomes: Approach and solve open-ended design problems in the field of process engineering
Place problems being solved within the context in which engineering processes take place
Be able to evaluate data from a range of sources to allow a coherent professional engineering technical report to be prepared
Gain advanced skills in the use of process engineering software
Be able to lay out a Chemical Process Engineering facility
Design and modify Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams
Access and use Australian Standards for equipment design
Use pinch and energy analysis techniques to minimise plantwide energy consumption
Perform HAZOP and QRA safety analyses
Use sustainable engineering techniques, such as Life Cycle Analysis

assessments.description: Seven in-class Assignments, worth 50% (in total), conducted in groups of 3-4 students, each to be completed within a 3-hour workshop session. Preparation time of approximately 4-5 hours for each workshop (including pre-reading and additional research tasks). All Intended Learning Outcomes (ILOs) are addressed in these assignments. Delivered throughout the semester starting from Week 1. Workshops use both allocated and self-selected team assignments, with peer assessment employed to moderate individual grades. 60 hours (of work required)

One take home written report, conducted individually, worth 15%, and due in Weeks 4-5 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 10 A4 pages (min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables). Overall time commitment of 15-20 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 6, 8. 20 hours (of work required)

One take home written report conducted individually, worth 10%, and due in Weeks 7-8 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 6 A4 pages (min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables.) Overall time commitment of approximately 10-13 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 10. 13 hours (of work required)

One take home written report conducted individually, worth 15%, and due in Week 10 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 10 A4 pages (min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables.) Overall time commitment of 15-20 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 9. 20 hours (of work required)

One take home written report, conducted in groups of 3-4 students, worth 10%, and due in Week 12 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 34 A4 pages for the group (page limit based on a group of 4, min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables.) Overall time commitment of 10-13 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, 12. 13 hours (of work required)

Semester 2.Contact hours: 1 x two hour lecture + 1 x three hour workshop per week

Subject notes: Within this subject there is a mix of learning and teaching methods employed:
Lectures where technical content is reviewed

Group-based time-limited workshops. Students are expected to complete reading tasks prior to these workshops. The pre-reading may or may not be based upon technical content previously delivered in lectures. Peer assessment techniques are employed within these workshops
One of the larger assignments (take home) uses industrially relevant computer simulation packages. Computer lab time/space is made available
When examining the wider context in which engineers operate, videos and other multimedia material are employed
Several (>10) external speakers also place the knowledge learnt/practiced in current engineering context.

Lecture notes and relevant multimedia material are provided throughout the course (available for download from LMS). Students are expected to use the library, internet and other resources to research some of the topics themselves.

Depending on year-to-year availability and relevance to the various chosen projects, typically more than 10 external (industry) speakers participate in this course. Alongside providing valuable context to the projects and detailing current practice, these external speakers also outline current employment opportunities within the profession and give overviews of their particular industrial area.
